paper_title.en: Oil sorbent material of heat treated wood fiber I. Effect of pyrolysate on oil sorption capacity
paper_title.ja: 熱処理による木質系吸油材料 (第1報) 吸油性に及ぼす熱分解物の影響

description.en:
Wood fibers heat-treated at 300-350 degreesC selectively remove oil from water systems. In the present paper, we examine the effect of pyrolysate, which is generated during heat treatment, on oil selectivity. The water sorption of heat-treated fiber decreased when the temperature increased. On the other hand, the oil sorption (except at 350 degreesC) showed much the same pattern, but the selectivity for oil was increased. Hot water and 1%-NaOH extracts decreased with increasing temperature. Ethanol-benzene extracts decreased at 200-250 degreesC and then increased at 300 degreesC. This result accounted for the disappearance of original extractive products and the generation of pyrolysate, which derived from lignin and polysaccharide, under GC/MS analysis. At 350 degreesC, the pyrolysates of lignin, such as 2-methoxyphenol, 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol, and 4-ethyl-2-methoxyphenol, were the major components of the extracts. Significant decreases of ethanol-benzene extracts occurred at 400 degreesC, and were caused by the secondary decomposition acid volatilization of these products.
These results indicate that the oil selectivity of heat-treated wood fiber depends on the increased hydrophobicity of polysaccharides and a decrease of hydrophilic components. The adhesion of lipophilic pyrolysate on the fiber surface was also an important contributor to oil selectivity.
